entry.title: Re: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi @sandeep_suggu ,

Thank you for this blog.

Also, I would like to add an alternative approach for checking special characters. Please see the example below:

PARAMETERS p_text TYPE string DEFAULT 'abc*'.

IF matches(
     val  = p_text
     pcre = '^[A-Za-z0-9]*$'
   ).
  WRITE / |No special character found: { p_text }|.
ELSE.
  WRITE / |Special character found: { p_text }|.
ENDIF.

With this approach, there is no need to explicitly handle special characters. The validation ensures that the string contains only alphanumeric characters (letters and digits).

entry.title: Event mesh design
entry.content:
Hi,
We are designing system to asynchronously handle traffic form multiple data centers where each data center can have several hostnames/servers. We currently have one API application that would consume the data from all of the data centers. Now, the first option is to design the queue for each data center and subscribe corresponding topic to each queue. So, if we have for example three data centers (in reality tens of them) HEC45, HEC44, HEC55 then we would have for example queue with this name Queue_HEC45 and topic name hec45 and so on. In this case the application would be subscribed and received on push notification the data from all of the data centers. 

What would be recommended approach to design such system? 
What do you think in terms of pursuing SAP Advanced Event Mesh (Solace) instead of SAP Event Mesh? 
We definitely need guaranteed delivery, dynamic message routing in case of more consumer applications.

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Problem with oData Batch Update of SalesOrderItem
entry.content:
Hi andrewpage,

I came across the same problem myself and found a fix:

The <headers> tag requires a <header> child so for yours it should look like this:

<headers>
  <header>
    <headerName>If-Match</headerName>
    <headerValue>W/"datetimeoffset'2025-09-10T07%3A27%3A59.4526150Z'"</headerValue>
  </header>
</headers>

Also, I don't know if it's strictly required or not but in my payload I added a header for the second batchChangeSetPart too with a wildcard value:

<headers>
  <header>
    <headerName>If-Match</headerName>
    <headerValue>*</headerValue>
  </header>
</headers>

 I know it's an old post but I hope this helps or maybe helps somebody else who comes across this issue.

entry.title: German Withholding Tax (Bauabzugsteuer)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently working on a project requiring the implementation of the German Construction Withholding Tax (Bauabzugsteuer), specifically under Sections 48-48d of the German Income Tax Act (EStG).

We are using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I am looking for guidance from anyone who has implemented this specific localization requirement in a public cloud environment. Specifically, I have the following questions:

  • Framework: Can the standard Extended Withholding Tax (WHT) framework be used to meet these legal requirements in the Public Cloud, or is there a specific localized solution/scope item?

  • Documentation: Are there specific Best Practices (Scope Items) or configuration guides available for this localization? I have checked the SAP Help Portal but would appreciate any pointers to specific "Bauabzugsteuer" documentation for Cloud.

  • Reporting: How are you handling the automated reporting and notifications to the tax authorities? Is this covered via the Advanced Compliance Reporting (ACR) / SAP Statutory Reporting framework?

If you have tackled this before or have any documentation/tips to share, I would be very grateful for your insights.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Generating and Translating Product Descriptions with SAP CX AI Toolkit
entry.content:
Challenge

Managing multilingual product data is an ongoing challenge, especially when catalogs must be localized for multiple regions and languages. Creating and updating descriptions manually is repetitive and time-consuming — and it’s easy for tone and quality to vary across markets. Even for teams running a single-language SAP Commerce Cloud  setup, large catalogs still need clear and consistent descriptions, which can’t always be produced by copywriting alone. As products shift faster and assortments grow, having some level of automation simply makes sense.

The Product Descriptions capability in SAP CX AI Toolkit supports this process by generating, editing, and translating product copy directly from your Commerce data. This blog walks through the end-to-end experience and highlights newer capabilities such as attribute-driven generation in bulk process

The only setup required is enabling templates and translation in the Commerce settings area, which are also user specific and optional. Once configured, users can work entirely from the Product Descriptions workspace. Only users with rights equivalent or higher than admin can access the settings.

Prerequisites

Product Descriptions relies on product data made available from SAP Commerce Cloud. Ensure that Commerce integration is active and product synchronization has completed successfully before using the feature. Additional prerequisites, including supported system versions and permissions, are listed here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/user/product-descriptions?locale=en-US#prerequisites

Overview of the Product Descriptions Workspace

The feature can be accessed from the main navigation panel. The workspace opens in Single View by default, which is intended for working on one item at a time. Users may switch to Bulk View at any point depending on the volume of products they wish to process.

Using Templates for Consistent Output

Templates define the style, tone, and structure of the generated description. Administrators can create these under Settings → Commerce → Templates.

The system ships with a Standard Description template, which remains available at all times. Additional templates may be created, enabled, or marked as default to better suit different brands or product categories. Template fields include the prompt text, tone, and length, and can optionally allow users to override these selections when generating descriptions. Templates are shared across both Single and Bulk Views.

See the Template setup section in help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/set-up/templates for field-level details.

Enabling Translation

To enable translation, users must activate language features in Settings. The Translation and Generation for Description toggles must be enabled, and supported target languages selected.

Learn more about this configuration in help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/set-up/configuration

Single-Product Description Generation

In Single View, users can generate or refine copy for a specific product. After selecting a template, optional custom instructions may be entered, and product attributes can be included to enrich the model’s context. Attribute selection becomes particularly useful for technical or structured products, as it allows product characteristics to be reflected directly in the content.

Once generated, the result appears in the editable panel. Users may revise wording and save changes. Publishing can be done later when generated descriptions are approved by the user, or the user can edit them before publishing.

More detail on this flow is available at Generate Single Product Description in the SAP Help Portal.

Translating a Single Product Description

The Translate Description tab supports multilingual output for the same product. Users choose whether the translation should reference an existing description or the AI-generated one. Multiple languages can be selected at once, and each language appears as a separate editable field.

Where a product does not yet have a base description in the preferred language, and there is no AI-generated description in the preferred language, the translation is not allowed—a helpful indicator that generation should occur first. Individual language edits can be saved and published independently.

Bulk Generation Across Multiple Products

Bulk View enables teams to generate descriptions for multiple items or an entire catalogue in a single action. The guided flow remains the same: choose a template, optionally add instructions, and select which attributes should apply to the prompt. Bulk generation always runs in the preferred language chosen in the Language settings.

A key enhancement in recent updates is the introduction of attribute selection within Bulk View, enabling more relevant description output without requiring per-product edits. Processing runs in the background, allowing users to continue working while results are generated.

 

Refer here for official documentation help.sap.com/docs/cx-ai-toolkit/user/generate-bulk-product-descriptions.

Bulk Translation and Editing

Once base descriptions exist, translation can also be performed in bulk. Users may translate all products, or only a filtered subset, into selected target languages. Products without a source description are automatically skipped.

Both generation and translation output can be reviewed directly in the bulk table or opened in a consolidated editor modal, where multiple languages may be adjusted in one place. After validation, descriptions can be published individually or through bulk actions.

Process All Functionality in Bulk

We have added feature to Generate/Translate/Publish/Delete for all the products present in the system in a single go with Generate All and similar button for all the four mentioned functionalities. Also, we have added multiple features for filter and sorting the products based on user requirements.

 

Conclusion

With flexible templates, granular control over attribute-driven prompts, and the ability to generate and translate descriptions across multiple products at once, the Product Descriptions feature offers an efficient path toward multilingual commerce readiness. The combination of Single and Bulk Views enables users to work iteratively at small scale or manage full catalog rollouts, supported by editable output and optional publishing workflows.

If you feel this blog post was helpful, give it a thumbs-up. Thank you for reading!

entry.title: 05 SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation -Complex Requirements Process Design Framework - Part 1
entry.content:
This blog provides a detailed walkthrough of the process design framework used to address complex requirements in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation projects. This blog is part of an ongoing series on SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, where we discuss real-world system challenges, architectural considerations, and the design strategies and approaches used to resolve them.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

The Process Design blog series is structured into two parts:

Part 1: Focuses on the process design framework, supporting tools, governance model, and ownership across functional and technical teams.

Part 2: Illustrates the process design approach through a detailed implementation example, highlighting design decisions, dependencies, and technical considerations.

1) Process  Design Overview : 

 In an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, Process Design is the bridge between business requirements and technical execution. The goal is to develop an optimal design that adheres to Global Best Practices and Clean Core guidelines, thereby reducing technical debt and ensuring long-term scalability.

When designing a process within SuccessFactors HCM , we focus on six core pillars:

  • Standardization & Fit-to-Standard:The process design must anchor on leading practices and must follow a Fit-to-Standard approach. Adopt the system’s pre-delivered processes as the baseline and introduce enhancements when a specific, localized requirement—such as a legal mandate or critical business gap—justifies a deviation from the core design.
  • Automation: Maximizing efficiency by eliminating manual workarounds. By leveraging the SuccessFactors Workflow Engine, we ensure requests are routed automatically to the correct stakeholders, reducing cycle times and human error.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing from the "outside-in." An effective process must be intuitive from the employee's perspective, prioritizing minimal clicks, mobile accessibility, and a frictionless interface.
  • Maintainability & Scalability :The architecture must be simple to support and easy to extend. We avoid over-engineering to enable the internal HRIS team to manage the system without constant external intervention.
  • Future-Proofing (Clean Core & Upgrades): By strictly following Clean Core guidelines and avoiding unsustainable customizations, we ensure that semi-annual SAP SuccessFactors releases/upgrades occur seamlessly without breaking existing functionality.
  • Security & Data Privacy:Protecting sensitive employee data through Role-Based Permissions (RBP). The design must ensure that data access is restricted based on the "need-to-know" principle, while remaining compliant with global regulations such as GDPR and the organization's compliance requirements.

2)Strategy for Identifying Process Design Items(Complex Requirements):

The primary goal of this exercise is to isolate high-complexity requirements early. By addressing these prior to the build phase, you ensure the project timeline remains realistic and the solution design is robust.

  • Multi-Channel Identification Sources : We use a three-pronged approach to capture requirements that demand detailed design:
  • HCM Analysis Results: We deep-dive into current pain points, existing legacy customizations, and unique customer requirements to see where the standard "out-of-the-box" system might fall short. Check the blog below on HCM system assessment and outcomes. https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/04-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-current-hcm-system-assessment-and/ba-p/14301718
  • Business Case Review: Customers often highlight their most "broken" or "critical" processes when justifying the project budget. We review these high-level business goals to extract specific technical requirements.
  • Collaborative Discovery: Through workshops, stakeholder interviews, and end-to-end (E2E) process walkthroughs, we identify "hidden" complexities that only emerge when discussing how data flows between departments.
  • Creating the "Process Design Inventory": Once identified, these items are consolidated into a centralized

      

  • Inventory of Process Design Items. This isn't just a list; it serves as a roadmap for the design phase. A typical inventory includes:
  • Identify early: Identifying these requirements before system configuration will have the following advantages. 
    •                 Right-Sizing the Design: Gives architects enough "runway" to build a scalable solution.
    •                 Risk Mitigation: Identifies potential "deal-breakers" before the system configuration begins.
    •                 Stakeholder Alignment: Ensures the customer and the implementation team agree on what "complex" actually means for this specific project. 

3) SAP SuccessFactors HCM Process Design Areas: 

When designing complex SAP SuccessFactors requirements, focusing on a single functional module in isolation often results in fragmented or “siloed” solutions. A robust process design must take a holistic view of the underlying technical architecture and clearly account for end-to-end data flows across the entire HR ecosystem. Where applicable, the design must also address migration considerations, including data readiness, Security aspects, transition strategy, and downstream system impacts, to ensure a scalable and sustainable solution. 

  • Integration: Design must account for how data flows between SF modules (e.g., Recruiting to Onboarding, or Employee Central to Payroll).The design must strictly adhere to the specified data mapping standards to avoid synchronization errors.
  • Data Migration: For example, When a decision is made to introduce Mass Positions in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, the process design must include a detailed end-to-end solution. This solution must clearly define how existing individual positions will be analyzed, converted, and migrated into mass positions. It should also address how these positions will be classified and aligned with the current HCM system, including required data cleansing, classification rules, and data migration approach.
  • Role-Based Permissions (RBP): Security is not an afterthought. Each process design must look at RBP  and impact; ignoring RBP design can lead to system lag or, worse, data privacy breaches.
  • Workflows: These define the "Business Logic." Design must account for who initiates a change, who approves it, and what happens if an approver is out of the office. Complex workflows often require custom Business Rules to trigger specific paths based on data (e.g., different approval paths for different countries).
  • External Systems: Most HCM landscapes include third-party vendors for benefits, background checks, or time tracking. Design must identify the impact on external systems and limit it to keep these systems in sync with your "Source of Truth" (SuccessFactors).
  • SAP BTP Extensions: When standard SuccessFactors "Out of the Box" functionality cannot meet a unique business requirement, SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is used to build custom extensions to achieve the requirements. 

4) Process Design guidelines:

Designing a Clean Core process in SAP SuccessFactors is about balancing standard product capabilities with your organization's unique business needs. The goal is to create a maintainable, scalable, and upgrade-friendly system by avoiding "technical debt" .

Below are the guidelines and impact considerations for a robust HCM Process Design.

  • Core Guidelines: Create your organization's clean core guidelines and make sure that SI Modules leads and architects are aligned on the guidelines, and the SI team also contributes to come up with guidelines. 
  • Refer to the below blog on clear core guidelines which are highly recommended for process design

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/02-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-clean-core-guidelines/ba-p/14289052

5) Process Design assets and tools: 

The SAP Process Library, delivered via SAP Signavio, is a powerful accelerator that provides organizations with a "head start" by offering pre-configured, industry-standard process maps. For HR specifically, this library aligns with SAP SuccessFactors best practices, ensuring your design is based on how the world's most efficient HR departments operate.

 6)SAP SuccessFactors HCM Process Design ownership (SI and Customer): 

  • Complexity Definition (SI and Customer): Together, the SI and Customer define what constitutes a "complex requirement" (e.g., custom integrations, complex picklists, or unique country-specific regulatory needs).
  • Current State Inventory and Requirements(Customer): The Customer takes the lead here, providing an inventory of existing HCM processes and requirements. The SI supports by providing templates or asking clarifying questions to ensure the inventory is exhaustive. 
  • Review of requirements and Process Design (SI) : The SI team leads the process design and walk-through with the customer business and technical owners.
  • Process Design Delivery (SI): The SI is responsible for documenting these designs in a format approved by the Customer .
  • Decision Logging ( Customer/SI): Every major design choice is recorded in a Decision Log by the SI. This prevents "circling back" on settled topics later in the project.
  •  Review & Sign-off (Customer): The Customer must perform a formal review. Approval here is the "green light" that the design meets the business requirements documented in Phase 1.
  •  Configuration/Implementation(SI): Once approved, the SI Team moves into the technical implementation .

 7. Process Design Lessons learned :

  • Building the right design requires skilled SI resources who can clearly understand business requirements and collaborate effectively with both the customer and internal SI teams to define the optimal solution.

  • SI resources involved in process design must be subject matter experts (SMEs) in their respective functional or technical areas.

  • Key SI resources must have a strong understanding of SAP-delivered assets, clean core guidelines, implementation design principles, and overall architecture standards.

  • Process design is not limited to functional modules; it must also address integration, data migration, and security considerations as applicable.

  • A robust governance framework should be established to review, validate, and formally approve designs prior to implementation.

  • Proof of Concept (POC) activities should be conducted where necessary to validate the proposed design and demonstrate its feasibility before full-scale deployment.

entry.title: The SAP Barbell Strategy: Applying Taleb’s Risk Logic to S/4HANA Projects
entry.content:
In the world of SAP S/4HANA transformations, project managers often try to "balance" risk. They aim for a middle-of-the-road approach: a bit of innovation here, a bit of customization there, and a moderate amount of testing but according to Nassim Taleb, author of The Black Swan and Antifragile, this "middle" is exactly where complex entities (like SAP projects) can die.

Taleb’s Barbell Strategy suggests that instead of being "medium-risky," you should be hyper-conservative on one side and hyper-aggressive on the other. By avoiding the middle, you protect yourself from total failure while keeping the door open for massive gains.

Here is a proposal to apply the Barbell Strategy to your SAP roadmap.

1. The Left Side: Extreme Safety (90% of Resources)

This side of the barbell is about survival. These are the areas where failure is an "existential risk"—meaning if they break, the company stops functioning. Here, we do not innovate; we focus on absolute robustness.

  • Data Migration: Bad financial or inventory data is a "Black Swan" event that can kill a Go-live. The Barbell approach requires extreme redundancy: multiple mock migrations, rigorous data cleansing, and third-party audits.
  • Clean Core (The Standard): Staying with the SAP Standard is your insurance policy. Every modification to the core system increases "fragility." By keeping the core clean, you ensure that future upgrades are seamless and the system remains stable.
  • Business Continuity: Can you issue an invoice on Day 1? Can you ship a pallet? This is the "Zero Day" requirement. Every resource here should be focused on ensuring the lights stay on when the legacy system is switched off.
  • Organizational Change Management (OCM): The biggest risk isn't technical—it's human. If your power users refuse to use the system, the project fails. Extreme safety means over-investing in training and user adoption early in the cycle.

2. The Right Side: Optionality and "Upside" (10% of Resources)

This is where you place small, speculative bets. These risks have a limited downside (if they fail, the cost is small) but an unlimited upside (if they work, they transform the business).

  • BTP Innovations: Use the SAP Business Technology Platform to run small AI or Machine Learning pilots. Automating a niche invoice-matching process might cost very little to try, but if it works, it saves thousands of man-hours.
  • Service Virtualization & Automated Simulation: Instead of waiting for third-party providers (banks, logistics partners, or external warehouses) to be "ready" for a test, you use tools like Int4 Suite or simulate virtualize their systems. The Unlimited Upside: You decouple your project timeline from external vendors. This can accelerate a global rollout by months. If you can test your SAP system’s integration with a "virtual" shipping partner before they even build their API, you find bugs early that would otherwise crash your Go-live.
  • Predictive Analytics: Experiment with advanced reporting models. Giving the C-suite a "future-view" that competitors lack provides a massive competitive advantage.
  • Low-Code/No-Code: Empower selected Power Users to build their own micro-tools using SAP Build. This encourages "bottom-up" innovation without touching the Clean Core.

3. The "Death Zone": The Fragile Middle (Avoid This)

The most dangerous part of an SAP project is the middle—the "moderate" risks that seem safe but are actually fragile. These offer no protection against catastrophe and no potential for high-reward innovation.

  • The "Medium Seniority" Pricing War - the Trap: Spending weeks in procurement battles trying to find consultants who are "experienced but affordable." Why it looks productive: You feel like you are being a "smart shopper" by avoiding the $2,000/day architect and rejecting the $300/day junior. Maybe you need to use the Barbell strategy once more? 
  • The "Perfect" Non-Core Process - the Trap: Spending months in workshops refining "nice-to-have" processes like Internal Office Supplies Requisition or Travel Expense Approval Workflows. Why it looks productive: You are "closing gaps" and making the system "user-friendly" for everyone in the company.

Do you know any other activities which fall into this category? 

Conclusion: Becoming Antifragile

To make your SAP implementation antifragile, stop trying to find a "balance."

  1. Protect the Base: Be a paranoid conservative regarding finance, master data, and the Clean Core (the left side).
  2. Hunt for Opportunity: Allocate a small, dedicated budget for risky, low-cost technological experiments that can give you a market edge (the right side).
  3. Cut the Middle: Refuse to accept mediocre talent, complex code modifications, and "vague" project scopes.

In the Barbell method, you aren't balancing risk; you are being extremely safe and extremely aggressive at the same time.

Additional Materials: Strengthening the Right Side of the Barbell

To move from the "Fragile Middle" to an Antifragile project state, you need the right tooling. While standard SAP tools handle the core, specialized solutions are required to manage the complexity of modern integrations and external dependencies.

Technical Spotlight: Int4 Suite

The Int4 Suite is a specialized SAP add-on designed to help enterprise companies master SAP Integration through Service Virtualization and automated API Testing.

In the context of the Barbell Strategy, Int4 Suite acts as a force multiplier for your "Right Side" (Optionality). It allows large organizations to ensure their interfaces, whether with banks, logistics providers, or external cloud platforms, work perfectly long before the actual SAP project Go-live. By virtualizing these third-party systems, you eliminate the "waiting game" for external vendors, allowing your team to test early, test often, and discover integration "Black Swans" when they are still cheap to fix.

Further Learning: Avoiding Project Delays

If you want to dive deeper into how to decouple your project timeline from external risks, SAP provides a dedicated learning path on this exact topic.

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

    • What you will learn: How to implement Service Virtualization to de-risk your S/4HANA transformation.

    • Why it matters: This course bridges the gap between theoretical risk management (the Barbell Strategy) and practical, technical execution.

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD By cloud connector and BTP Destination call (internal network) API
entry.content:
Hi peter,

I followed the steps one by one. However, when making the final call, I encountered an exception:
CATCH cx_web_http_client_error INTO DATA(lx_web_http_client_error).
this is my code:

    DATA lo_cota TYPE REF TO ztwins.
    DATA lt_output TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string.
     TRY.
        lo_cota = NEW ztwins( ).
        DATA(lo_client) = lo_cota->create_web_http_client( ).
        DATA(req) = LO_client->get_http_request(  ).
        req->set_text( lv_sjson ).
        DATA(lo_response) = lo_client->execute( if_web_http_client=>get ).
        DATA(ls_status) = lo_response->get_status( ).
        lv_rjson = lo_response->get_text( ).
      CATCH cx_communication_target_error INTO DATA(lx_communication_target_error).
        APPEND lx_communication_target_error->get_text( ) TO lt_output.
      CATCH cx_web_http_client_error INTO DATA(lx_web_http_client_error).
        APPEND lx_web_http_client_error->get_text( ) TO lt_output.

    ENDTRY.

entry.title: Re: How to change the FYV in Make Company Code Seeting -...
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, only the configurable template fiscal year variant SZ is available for assignment. You cannot assign K4 directly to specific company codes. Instead, you should configure SZ to replicate the K4 settings (calendar year with 12 posting periods and 4 special periods but technically the variant is SZ.). This way, the two company codes will effectively follow K4 rules, while the system remains harmonized under SZ. Assigning different fiscal year variants to different company codes is not supported in Public Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Comments on BW/BPC live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Dieter,

So the first thing I need to know: have you given each MEMBER of the row and column structure a technical name? If so the remark in my blog above holds true:

  • If the restricted key figure has been given a technical name then we use the technical name as a key and do NOT resolve the selection. If you use a variable in the restriction then the variable name and the actual value of the variable are used in the key for the comment as well.

(the remark only talks about the restricted key figure but it is also true when you use a technical ID for a member of the second structure that does not involve the key figure.)

If this is the case you have to check get the technical name of the structure members from the context of the document and - if applicable - get the variable values that have been used when the comment was created. If you go back to the query you should be able to find the corresponding structure elements. If you now set the corresponding variable values you should find the comments. As the document service uses the ID of the structure element and NOT the underlying selection (this would be the case if you do NOT use an ID for the structure element), when building a query that uses the same underlying selection for a given cell but without the ID of the structure element then you would NOT see the comments. Is this maybe the problem you are facing?

Best regards

Gerd

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the “alternative payee” field is not available for customers in Accounts Receivable. Instead, the standard way to achieve this requirement is to assign the alternative customer (3000) as the Payer partner function in the BP master of customer 2000. When invoices are posted to 2000, the system will automatically set 3000 as the payer, so incoming payments (including partial payments) can be posted against 3000. This ensures that the invoice remains with customer 2000 for documentation, but settlement is handled by customer 3000.

entry.title: Re: Onboarding I-9 Form Verification Requiring Upload for...

Dear @JulieMcSwain 

Yes, it is required now.

USCIS Form I-9 - https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-onboarding/implementing-onboarding/uscis-form-i-9

  • The new hire must present one document from List A, or one document from both List B and List C. If the new hire presents a combination of List B and List C documents, then the List B document must contain a photograph.

Previously, the application permitted HR users to submit Form I-9 Section 2 without uploading at least one of the required documents (either a List A document or both List B and List C documents). No blocking or required enforcement was in place, leading to incomplete compliance records. 

This has been changed, making sure SAP is compliant with legal requirements.

US I-9 Central - https://www.uscis.gov/i-9-central/form-i-9-acceptable-documents

Best regards,
Jacson
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Price in Work Order
entry.content:
Why it happens only for stock components is because, stock components are materials that are managed in inventory (MM). Their valuation is maintained at plant level (valuation area). When you add a stock component to a work order, SAP pulls the valuation price (standard price or moving average) from the material master in that plant. That is why the price depends on the plant + material combination.

Non‑stock components (e.g. direct procurement items, services, consumables) are not held in inventory. They don’t have plant‑level valuation in the material master. Their cost is determined from purchase info records, planned price, or manually entered values in the order. Since there’s no plant valuation, you don’t see the same plant‑dependent price behavior.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: except if someone drops a table, then only a full database restore or Recyclebin option can be used to recover a dropped table. flashback table will fail if the DLL is changed. Flashback only works if data alone is changed, not the table structure itself.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: Except that flashback table only works if the data alone was changed. If the table is altered or dropped, you cannot flashback the table, then you need Recyclebin or to do a database backup recovery to recover the table or restore it to another instance and copy the table. Both would take more time and effort than if we had Recyclebin enabled.

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: Why you don’t see customer 3000 in FB70 / Post Incoming Payment is because, when you assign customer 3000 as the Payer in the BP master of customer 2000, the effect is at the SD billing level. That means, when you create a sales order → billing document → FI posting, the system automatically substitutes the payer (3000) in the accounting document. In other words, the invoice posted from SD will show 3000 as the account in FI, even though the sales order was created for 2000. If you post a purely FI invoice manually in FB70, the system does not look at SD partner functions. FB70 is a direct FI transaction, so it always posts to the customer you enter (2000). That’s why you don’t see 3000 there. To achieve the desired behavior, invoices should be created through SD billing so that the FI posting is automatically made to the payer (3000). Incoming payments, including partial payments, can then be posted against 3000.

entry.title: Re: How to group requirements across several WBS using va...
entry.content:
Why PMMO and GPD don’t fit is because, PMMO (Pegging, Distribution, and Summarization) is designed for non‑valuated project stock only. Great for logistics grouping, but not usable when you need valuated stock and FI postings.

GPD (Grouping, Pegging, Distribution) is technically supports both valuated and non‑valuated stock, but in S/4HANA 2021 it is deprecated. It only creates CO postings (in non‑zero versions), not FI postings → breaks your reporting and COGS alignment. So neither fits your requirement for valuated stock + FI postings.

Standard Options in S/4HANA 2021 are

1. Valuated Project Stock + Combined Orders without GPD
Keep each WBS element as the account assignment for its child orders. Use Combined Orders only for the common cutting/bending operations. After the header operation is confirmed, split into child orders pegged to the correct WBS. This way, costs flow to the WBS via the child orders, and FI postings are created because stock is valuated.

Downside: you lose the automatic “requirements grouping” across WBS, but you preserve FI integrity.

2. Network Activities with Valuated Stock
Instead of grouping via GPD, model the shared operations as network activities assigned to multiple WBS elements. You can issue materials to a network activity, capture costs, and then settle to the WBS. This gives you FI postings (because stock is valuated) and allows you to analyze costs per WBS. More flexible than combined orders, but requires careful design of networks.

3. Custom Extensibility for Grouping
Some customers build a custom grouping logic using extensibility (e.g. CDS views, allocation rules) to redistribute costs from a combined header order to multiple WBS elements. This way, you run one large production order, but at confirmation/settlement the system allocates costs to the relevant WBS. This preserves valuated stock and FI postings, but requires development effort.

4. Strategic Split of Projects
If grouping across WBS is essential, one option is to split the project definition so that the combined order can be tied to a single WBS/project, then allocate costs back to the “real” WBS hierarchy via settlement rules. Not elegant, but sometimes used when reporting requirements are strict.

entry.title: Re: How to group requirements across several WBS using valuated project stock?
entry.content:
A few clarifying points. PMMO is the latest improved version of GPD.  Both PMMO and GPD always required Non-Valuated Project Stock.  GPD does do FI postings, it is in the last Distribution step.  

Just Requirements Grouping can be used separate from GPD and can be used with Valuated Project Stock.  It also can be used in S/4HANA.

When you want to group requirements are you talking about grouping across projects or just within a project?  Either are possible.  This dictates how you do the grouping and subsequent Combined Order.

The Combined Orders use complicates the WBS account assignment.  I think all of the Production Orders in a Combined Order would need to have the same WBS account assignment.

entry.title: Re: SAP CAP Lessons Learned: Hybrid Development with On-Premise SAP System
entry.content:
Hi @Ramjee_korada , 

Timeout errors usually means the connection is not setup correctly.

You'll have to use the command: 

cf ssh s4apitestproj-srv -L 2003:connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003

You correctly updated the onpremise_proxy_host value, but forgot to match the onpremise_proxy_port value.

The app by default will try to send the request to: connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003.

You'll first need to override the host to localhost. Then connect SSH to your remote app. Finally, tell your own computer that every time are request arrives at localhost:2003, it must forward - via ssh - to connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003.

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI – SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI – Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI – MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

entry.title: Understanding SAP HANA Backup and Recovery - Technical Scope, Dependencies, and Design Boundaries
entry.content:
Introduction
SAP HANA provides a comprehensive and explicitly documented framework for backup and recovery. The core components of this framework are data backups, log backups, the backup catalog, and well-defined recovery procedures.

In many operational or architectural discussions, these components are treated as isolated features. From a technical perspective, however, recoverability is not a property of an individual backup. Recoverability emerges only from the complete and consistent backup chain over time, governed by strict dependencies that are explicitly documented by SAP.

This article consolidates SAP-documented SAP HANA backup and recovery mechanisms into a single coherent technical model.

Its objective is to make documented dependencies, scope, and design boundaries explicit, supporting sound architecture decisions, recovery validation planning, and technically correct discussions.

All statements in this article are derived from official SAP Help Portal and SAP HANA SQL Reference documentation.

1. Documented Core Components of SAP HANA Backup and Recovery
1.1 Data Backups
Data backups create a transaction-consistent image of the SAP HANA database at a defined point in time. SAP HANA supports different data backup types, such as full, differential, and incremental backups, each designed for specific operational and recovery scenarios.

A data backup establishes a single, consistent restore point.
However, a data backup does not define recoverability on its own.

From a technical perspective:

  • A data backup is a mandatory prerequisite for recovery.
  • Recoverability beyond the data backup timestamp depends on the availability of subsequent log backups and catalog metadata.

This distinction is explicitly reflected in SAP documentation.

SAP Help Portal reference
Backups (Overview)

Key technical boundary
A successful data backup defines a restore point, not continuous recoverability.

1.2 Log Backups
Log backups record all database changes that occur after a data backup. When log backup is enabled, SAP HANA generates log backups continuously.

From a recovery perspective, log backups are technically essential for:

  • recovery to the most recent state
  • point-in-time recovery

Log backups form a strictly sequential chain.
Recovery procedures that rely on log replay require this chain to be complete and uninterrupted.

If a required log backup segment is missing, corrupted, or no longer retained, recovery beyond that point is technically impossible, regardless of how many data backups exist.

SAP Help Portal reference
Log Backups

Key technical boundary
Log backups are not optional for recovery beyond a data backup timestamp.

1.3 Backup Catalog
The backup catalog stores metadata describing:

  • all data and log backups
  • their timestamps
  • their relationships and dependencies

SAP HANA uses the backup catalog to determine:

  • which backups exist
  • which backup chains are complete
  • which recovery targets are feasible

The backup catalog is therefore a technical dependency, not auxiliary metadata.

Even if backup files exist on disk or external storage, standard recovery procedures cannot be evaluated or executed without a consistent backup catalog.

SAP Help Portal reference
Backup Catalog

Additional technical detail:
What Information Is in the Backup Catalog?

Key technical boundary
Without a backup catalog, recoverability is limited and cannot be reliably determined.

2. Documented Recovery Capabilities and Scope
SAP HANA provides explicitly documented recovery procedures. The chosen recovery type determines which parts of the backup chain must be available.

2.1 Recovery to the Most Recent State
This recovery procedure restores the database to the latest possible point in time by:

  • restoring a suitable data backup
  • replaying all available log backups after that backup

Technical prerequisites:

  • a valid data backup
  • a complete and uninterrupted log backup chain
  • a consistent backup catalog

2.2 Point-in-Time Recovery
Point-in-time recovery restores the database to a specific timestamp.

From a technical standpoint:

  • all log backups covering the requested time range must be available
  • the backup catalog must describe the full chain

If required log backups for the selected interval are missing, recovery to that timestamp is not possible, even if older data backups exist.

SAP Help Portal reference
Point-In-Time Recovery of a Primary System

3. Recoverability as a Chain Property (Technical Dependency Model)
Recoverability is not a property of an individual backup artifact.

From a technical perspective, recovery depends on the combined availability of:

  • a suitable data backup
  • all required log backups following that backup
  • the corresponding backup catalog entries

SAP HANA tooling evaluates these dependencies using catalog-driven logic when determining feasible recovery options.

This behavior is explicitly reflected in the SAP HANA SQL Reference.

SAP HANA SQL Reference
BACKUP LIST DATA Statement

Documented boundary
Without a backup catalog, recovery capabilities are restricted

4. Retention and Recovery Window
Retention settings define how long data and log backups are kept.
From a technical standpoint, retention directly defines the recovery window.

If required log backups are no longer available:

  • recovery beyond that point is technically impossible
  • older data backups do not extend recoverability

This follows directly from SAP HANA’s log replay mechanics.

SAP Help Portal reference
Planning Your Backup and Recovery Strategy

5. Backup Operation Success vs. Recoverability
SAP HANA reports the success or failure of individual backup operations.

From a technical perspective:

  • backup success confirms that a single operation completed
  • recoverability is evaluated only at restore time

Recovery feasibility depends on:

  • chain completeness
  • catalog availability
  • chosen recovery target

Backup operations are events.
Recovery is a reconstruction procedure.
These are technically distinct concepts.

6. Separation from Availability Mechanisms
SAP HANA provides availability mechanisms such as system replication to reduce downtime. Backup and recovery address restoration to a previous state.

These mechanisms serve different documented objectives and must be designed and validated independently.

(Availability mechanisms are intentionally not covered in this article.)

Summary
SAP HANA provides all documented technical mechanisms required for reliable backup and recovery.

Recoverability is defined by the availability and consistency of the complete backup chain over time:

  • data backups
  • log backups
  • backup catalog

Understanding these documented dependencies and boundaries is essential for technically sound architecture design, realistic recovery expectations, and precise operational discussions.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: Q4/2025 Feature Highlights
entry.content:
The fresh batch of features delivered in Q4 2025 brings powerful new tools designed to make your integrations smarter, faster, and more resilient. From AI-powered recommendations that simplify troubleshooting, to streamlined connectivity with top platforms like Amazon Kinesis and Box, these updates are crafted to boost your operational efficiency and keep you ahead of the curve. Read on to explore how these innovations can transform your integration experience.

Artificial Intelligence

AI-based intelligent recommendations for detected API anomalies

This AI enhancement builds on anomaly detection to explain what changed, why it likely happened, and what to do next, cutting triage and speeding recovery. Embedded in API Management, it surfaces guidance alongside alerts with one-click actions and optional “intelligent healing.”

The included capabilities - Insights, Causes, and Recommendations - enable faster response to error spikes, latency surges, and abnormal traffic patterns, improving reliability and operational efficiency for API owners and teams. See how to get started in this blog post and review the Documentation.

 Connectivity and Adapters

  • Amazon Kinesis receiver adapter: facilitates and accelerates connectivity to Amazon Kinesis Data Streams, streamlining data communication and enhancing real-time data processing.
  • Box receiver adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to Box and enables you to access components on Box.
  • Microsoft OneNote receiver adapter: automates common business operations by integrating MS OneNote with other business applications. It connects an SAP Integration Suite tenant to a remote system using HTTP protocol.
  • Azure Service Bus adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to Azure Service Bus.
  • MongoDB receiver adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to MongoDB.
  • Poll Enrich Step in FTP sender adapter: reads (poll) messages from FTP server and adds the content to the original message in the middle of the message processing sequence.

New data space integration package

The data space integration package helps supply chain partners exchange data securely and self-sovereignly within data spaces. It includes two components: a data space connector for secure, sovereign data exchange, and a decentralized identity wallet for sharing trustworthy, verifiable data. Read all details in the blog post.

Data Center Availability 🇩🇪 🇮🇹 🇦🇪

Customers can now run SAP Integration Suite in four new data centers: on SAP infrastructure in Frankfurt, Sankt Leon-Rot (both in Germany) and in the United Arab Emirates; and additionally, one in Italy on Amazon Web Services.

Event-driven Integration 

Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are small, event-driven connectors that link applications to an Advanced Event Mesh as on-ramps (event sources) or off-ramps (event targets), avoiding brittle point-to-point ties so changes stay localized and low-risk. By focusing on narrowly defined tasks, they are easier to design, adapt, and scale, delivering high-throughput, real-time streams via pub/sub and letting you add more Micro-Integrations per task as demand grows. Available in the Cloud Console, they provide management and observability for integrations between external systems and event brokers or meshes, resulting in greater agility, faster data distribution, and flexibility to use the best-fit technologies at the source and target. Find more details and the currently available micro-integrations in the blog post.

Event Mesh integration with SAP Cloud ALM for health monitoring

SAP Integration Suite’s Event Mesh now integrates with SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring to regularly collect and display broker vitals, such as active connections, message consumers, message queues, spool usage, and broker state, on the CALM dashboard. Customers can customize thresholds for each metric (except broker state), view 14 days of history, and receive warning notifications when values reach 80% (orange) and 90% (red) of the defined thresholds, enabling proactive monitoring and alerts for Event Mesh health. Set up and further details can be found here.

Migration support from Event Mesh capability to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Great news to facilitate your system modernization: SAP provides technical- and process-oriented migration support to help customers move from the Event Mesh capability in SAP Integration Suite to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh, scaling smoothly from basic scenarios to a richer, more powerful event-driven foundation. This includes support for migrating events so applications can communicate asynchronously in real time across distributed landscapes with support for various protocols, enabling teams to start simple, grow confidently, and modernize without disruption.

B2B Integration

Support for the SFTP adapter and Alerting of failed B2B interchanges in Trading Partner Management

SAP Integration Suite’s Trading Partner Management now supports SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol), available in both standard and premium editions and via the SAP BTP Enterprise Agreement. Users can read and write files to their own or trading partners’ SFTP servers and, when defining systems, can choose SFTP sender and receiver adapters.

Additionally, SAP Integration Suite extends Trading Partner Management by publishing B2B interchange data to SAP Cloud ALM for centralized monitoring and rapid detection of failed transactions. Using SAP Cloud ALM, you can configure granular scenario specific alerts that filter by details such as trading partners or message types to receive targeted notifications and act quickly on issues.

Process Integration

Basic authentication on Edge Integration Cell

SAP Integration Suite’s Edge Integration Cell now supports basic HTTP authentication using a client ID and client secret during temporary connectivity loss to SAP BTP. This enables simple sender authentication for testing with minimal configuration and allows integration flow processing and API artifact invocations using clientId and clientsecret while SAP BTP is unreachable.

Advanced checks in Groovy scripts

SAP Integration Suite’s Cloud Integration designer now offers advanced checks for Groovy scripts, helping developers analyze and prepare custom integration flows for future runtime version upgrades. A new “ensure upgrade readiness” guideline recommends supported libraries and classes and can automatically update scripts to align with upgrade requirements. See all information in the respective documentation.

Service interface artifact creation In Cloud Integration

SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration now supports creating and editing service interface artifacts directly in the workspace, aligning with an API first outside in development approach and supporting existing Enterprise Services Repository use cases. These artifacts enable proxy generation in ABAP backends for smooth integration into ABAP based systems. The capability is available in the multi cloud environment and allows native creation of service interface artifacts in your Cloud Integration tenant.

----

  • For a sneak peek into what’s in store for 2026, check out the road map explorer and the SAP TechEd 2025 News Guide
  • Join the integration community and connect with other integration developers!

entry.title: SAP Group Reporting Implementation: Architecture and Methodology for Success
entry.content:
Hello dear colleagues and readers, i`d like to appreciate you for your 
attention to this material, what, i`m sure, will assist you during your Group Reporting solution implementation.

Let`s get started

Agenda:
1) Group Reporting. Why business needs this Solution,
2) SAP Activate methodology, nutshell,
3) High lvl overview Group Reporting implementation steps,
4) Successful Go Life timeline, linkage SAP Activate Methodology and Group Reporting,
5) DEV - TEST - PROD consistency must be aligned between these instances,
6) Unit test, SIT, UAT. Main think and difference.


GROUP REPORTING: Why Business Needs This Solution
SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting is an integrated consolidation solution that
helps organizations efficiently collect, aggregate, validate, and prepare
financial data for consolidated financial statement reporting.

1. DATA MONITOR - Responsible for:
- Collecting financial data from consolidation units (local companies),
- Validating data quality at the source level,
- Preparing and transforming data before consolidation,
- Performing local reporting tasks per consolidation unit.

2. CONSOLIDATION MONITOR - Responsible for:
- Consolidating data across all consolidation units at group level,
- Executing consolidation procedures (intercompany eliminations, currency translations, investment consolidation),
- Performing group-level validations and adjustments,
- Generating consolidated financial statements.

DELIVERABLES - Consolidated Financial Statements:
The solution produces comprehensive consolidated financial statements including:
* Consolidated Balance Sheet (Statement of Financial Position),
* Consolidated Profit & Loss Statement (Income Statement),
* Statement of Changes in Equity,
* Consolidated Cash Flow Statement,
* Segment Reporting (if required by business),
* Additional reports based on business requirements.

KEY DIFFERENTIATORS:
Universal Journal Integration:
Unlike legacy consolidation tools (like BPC), Group Reporting is fully embedded in
SAP S/4HANA and directly accesses the Universal Journal (ACDOCA/ACDOCU).
This creates a "single version of truth" - meaning local operational data
and group - level consolidation data come from the same source, eliminating
data replication and reconciliation challenges.

Real-Time Consolidation:
Group Reporting enables continuous consolidation rather than batch - based
processing, allowing consolidation to be performed before and after the monthly close.

Comprehensive Consolidation Capabilities:
1) Full consolidation of subsidiaries,
2) Equity method consolidation for joint ventures and associates,
3) Automatic intercompany transaction elimination,
4) Currency translation per regulatory requirements (IFRS,US - GAAP),
5) Investment consolidation (goodwill, NCI),
6) Data validation at multiple levels (reported, standardized, consolidated),
7) Multi - dimensional reporting (by Legal entity, Profit Center, Cost Center and another).

Why it`s important for business:
1) Faster consolidation cycles,
2) Improved data quality,
3) Better visibility and transparency,
4) Compliance from regulatory point of view,
5) Reduced manual effort,
6) Flexibility for complex organizations.


SAP Activate methodology, nutshell
It`s a standard Best Practice implementation road map of S4HANA Solutions, and sure it`s absolutely
relevant for Group Reporting.
Please take a look at these 6 main steps, it's critical for timeline perspective alignment:





Successful Go Life timeline, linkage SAP Activate Methodology and Group reporting

I would like to emphasize a critical point regarding alignment with the roadmap and implementation approach
aligned with Road Map and implementation.
It is essential to strictly adhere to the proposed SAP Activate methodology all standard steps - both in terms of gathering business information and implementing the corresponding system configuration.
Any delays or deviations from the planned timeline will inevitably impact the Go - Live schedule and all associated consequences.
If any deliverable is at risk of missing its deadline, it is crucial to immediately notify the Project Management persons so they can respond promptly and implement corrective measures to get the project back on track.

DEV - TEST - PROD consistency must aligned between these instances

When you configure Group Reporting in DEV system, that configuration must be exactly replicated in TEST and PROD systems.
If they're different = disaster.
SAP provides Transport Management System (TMS) to move configuration between environments.




Unit test, SIT, UAT. Main think and difference

Unit Testing can be performed based on abstract data during initial configuration activities, primarily to ensure that individual system components work as expected in isolation. Unit tests validate single configuration elements without considering how they interact with other parts of the system.

System Integration Testing (SIT) activities must be performed based on REAL BUSINESS DATA with EXPECTED RESULTS provided by the Finance team. For example, when testing P&L Functional Area with Reporting Rules, the Finance team must provide the consolidated P&L that should be produced as output. SIT validates that all configuration components work together end-to-end and produce the correct consolidated financial statements.

User Acceptance Testing (UAT) is performed by the Finance/IT business department using actual business data and real consolidation scenarios. During UAT, business users validate that the system meets their requirements and they can perform their daily work. UAT concludes with explicit sign - off from Finance confirming the system is ready for Go - Live.

The critical difference:
1) Unit tests validate components individually,
2) SIT validates the entire system with real data against expected results,
3) UAT validates that business users accept the solution before Go-Live.


I hope my experience will assists you in the next implementation projects.
Many thanks for your attention, all the best.

Let`s keep in touch.
https://www.linkedin.com/in/eugene-kavaleu/

entry.title: SAP Service and Asset Manager 2511 Now Available – What’s New?
entry.content:
SAP Service and Asset Manager continues to expand mobile execution across service, maintenance, and logistics processes. The 2511 release introduces new confirmation scenarios, more flexible synchronization options, workflow and usability enhancements, expanded logistics and warehouse capabilities, and broader forms support—helping field teams collaborate more effectively, reduce manual effort, and execute work with greater accuracy and control.

Key features delivered in the SAP Service and Asset Manager 2511 release

Confirmation scenarios

Confirmation scenarios enable technicians to apply confirmations using secure, QR code–based authentication, improving collaboration, accountability, and quality assurance.

When working with an operation or suboperation, two technicians use their devices to complete a confirmation. An authorized or supporting technician generates a QR code, which is scanned to automatically populate confirmation details and reduce manual entry.

Cooperation

The primary technician records work performed by a supporting technician by scanning a QR code generated on the supporting technician’s device, creating a clear and auditable record of collaborative work.

Verification

Verification supports a four-eyes principle by requiring an authorized technician to review and confirm completed work. Verification can be configured as mandatory, preventing confirmation until the review is completed.

Upload-only syncing

Upload-only syncing allows users to upload recorded transactions without triggering an immediate delta download. This decouples upload and download activities, improving sync efficiency in offline or low-connectivity environments.

Technicians can upload transactions after completing a job, finishing a shift, or completing a work cycle, while still initiating a full delta sync whenever updated data is required.

Maintenance workflow enhancements

Workflow and usability enhancements help technicians collaborate more effectively and complete work faster.

Improvements to split capacity assignment

Split capacity assignment now better supports multi-technician execution. Technicians can view all assigned splits, track split-specific dates, include split numbers in confirmations, and record confirmations on behalf of other users—improving flexibility while maintaining accurate effort tracking.

Tabbed layout for the home page

A new tabbed home page layout organizes content into clearly defined sections, enabling faster navigation and easier access to relevant information.

Enhanced navigation for related orders and notifications

Navigation to related orders and notifications has been streamlined. If the related object is available on the device, users are taken directly to it. If not, an online search can be initiated from the related items list to retrieve the required details.

Advanced map features

Mapping enhancements include support for vector tile basemaps and improved offline map handling with support now for .tpk and .geodatabase files as well as side-loading of map cache. Technicians can use vector and raster maps offline, view GIS feature layer attributes, and trigger actions such as completing forms or measurement readings directly from the map, improving performance and productivity for location-based work.

Field Service Technician updates

New capabilities support external technicians and improve schedule visibility for field service teams.

External Field Service Technician persona

A new persona supports integration with FSM Crowd Service, enabling third-party technicians to view and execute service orders directly in the mobile app. External technicians can record time, materials, and expenses without requiring individual SAP user IDs, increasing flexibility and field productivity.

Enhanced calendar with event and task indicators

A new calendar control on the home page provides visual indicators for open and overdue tasks, helping technicians quickly prioritize work. Daily, weekly, and monthly views improve schedule awareness and task management.

Expanded logistics and warehouse support

Logistics teams gain expanded mobile access to core SAP processes, enabling faster and more accurate execution in warehouse and field logistics scenarios.

Inbound delivery support for Extended Warehouse Management

The Extended Warehouse Clerk persona now supports inbound delivery processing on mobile. Users can search for inbound deliveries, update documents, create warehouse tasks, perform packing, and post goods receipt for single or multiple items.

Return and packing features

Field logistics operators can initiate returns by product or by order and perform packing activities directly on mobile, including packing containers, assigning them to voyages, sealing, and dispatching—streamlining logistics execution and improving visibility.

Expanded forms support

Forms capabilities have been extended to reduce manual entry and support safety-related workflows.

Dynamic predefined text in smartform fields

Smartform fields can now display dynamic predefined text, such as service order numbers, directly in input controls, improving consistency and reducing manual data entry on Customer Service and S/4HANA systems.

Safety Technician persona support for SAP Dynamic Forms

The Safety Technician persona now supports SAP Dynamic Forms, allowing creation, editing, and submission of forms attached to work permits, isolation certificates, and other safety-related certificates. Forms attached to other object types remain read-only.

Configuration details

Features described above may be optional and not be default-enabled, and integrations with other SAP products may require additional licensing.

Please refer to Configuring Features and Personas in SAP Service and Asset Manager to learn about assigning personas and visit the Features and Personas Configuration Matrix to see which features are in-scope for each persona .

Release available now

The application is publicly available and includes an offline demo mode for viewing and testing the extensive functionality with maintenance technician, field service technician, safety technician, and inventory clerk personas included.

The application metadata is now available for licensed customers and partners on the SAP Support Portal Software Center and the mobile client may be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.

Share your ideas

We encourage you to learn more about submitting improvement requests to influence future releases of SAP Service and Asset Manager.

entry.title: Re: How to group requirements across several WBS using va...
entry.content: Thank you very much Ken for answering this. We want MRP to group requirements across more than 1 WBS element but always within the same Project. For example, let's say we are producing a steel tower with 6 sections; for us this is 6 WBS elements within the same Project. The same FERT material A appears 2x in each section so we want MRP to plan and then we will make  one Combined Order of 12 pieces of material A; we don't want to make 6 combined orders of 2 pieces each. When using the CPD model we encountered the problems as Lakshmipathi detailed in the first 2 paragraphs of his answer.
